references: As mentioned, some of the existing sign-based methods like [12, 43] do not adopt the standard squared â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}-norm of gradients as the metric for the convergence rate analysis. Thus, it is tricky to make a fair comparison between them and the proposed zğ‘§z-SignFedAvg. In Appendix A, we provide a detailed discussion and summarize the convergence rates of some representative algorithms in Table 2.

Table 2 summarizes the key features of a few representative stochastic sign-based methods and the proposed zğ‘§z-SignFedAvg, including the convergence rate, metric used in the convergence rate analysis, extra assumptions other than A.1-A.3 in Assumption 1, and whether the algorithm can achieve linear speedup and allow multiple local SGD steps.

Among the works in Table 2, the setting considered by [43] is closest to ours. [43] proposed an algorithm that can achieve the convergence rate ğ’ªâ€‹(Ï„âˆ’14)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ14\mathcal{O}(\tau^{-\frac{1}{4}}) with the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}-norm of gradients as the metric. We remark that this is inferior to the convergence rate ğ’ªâ€‹(Ï„âˆ’12)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ12\mathcal{O}(\tau^{-\frac{1}{2}}) with the squared â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}-norm as the metric. To illustrate this point, we denote a series of vector as {Î±1,â€¦,Î±Ï„,â€¦}subscriptğ›¼1â€¦subscriptğ›¼ğœâ€¦\{\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{\tau},...\} with Î±iâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\alpha_{i}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}. If now

In Table 2, we assume both [5] and [23] adopt the quantizer in (14). Generally speaking, this type of unbiased quantization usually requires much more bits than sign-based compression to obtain a good performance, which is also verified empirically in Appendix E. It is also worthwhile to mention that the FedPAQ in [42] and the FedCOM in [23] are equivalent in algorithm, but only the latter one considers the heterogeneous scenario theoretically.

references:
Settings. 
We followed a setting similar to [28] for the experiment on EMNIST. We adopted the client-level differential privacy, i.e., to treat each client as a single data point, and perturbed the local gradients before sending them to server. We also used the technique of privacy amplification by client sub-sampling in [28, 21]. For both DP-FedAvg and DP-SignFedAvg, the same CNN in Section 4.2 was used, and the maximum norm for clipping was set to 0.01. We sampled 100 clients at each communication round and ran both algorithms for 500 communication rounds.
Similar to [28], we run the experiments under the privacy budgets Îµ=[1,2,4,6,8,10]ğœ€1246810\varepsilon=[1,2,4,6,8,10]. In Table 8, we provide the hyperparameter for DP-FedAvg and DP-SignFedAvg for all levels of privacy budgets. Unlike previous experiments, the noise scales used in this experiment were determined by the privacy budget and the privacy accounting method in [39].
